question: What is the Moon's phase called when its lighted half faces the Sun and its dark half faces Earth?

content.source_1: The half of the Moon that faces the Sun is sunlit (“day side”), and the half facing away from the Sun is dark; the phase depends on how much of the sunlit half is pointed toward Earth.
content.source_2: At new moon, the Moon lies between Earth and the Sun (conjunction), so essentially none of the sunlit hemisphere faces Earth and the Earth-facing side appears dark.
content.source_3: A lunar eclipse can occur only at full moon, when Earth is between the Sun and the Moon (opposition).
content.source_4: During a total lunar eclipse, the Moon’s Earth-facing side is darkened because it passes through Earth’s umbral shadow.
content.source_5: At full moon when there is no eclipse, the hemisphere facing Earth is the sunlit half and the disk appears fully illuminated.
content.source_6: When none of the sunlit hemisphere is visible from Earth, the phase is called “new moon.”
